ticket.title: When a new Rails application is created by "rails new", autoload_paths instead of load_paths should be put in the generated application.rb
ticket.original-body:
I have just switched my existing Rails 3.0.0.beta4 application to 3.0.0.rc. And I got an error,
/Users/[user_name]/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-rc2/gems/railties-3.0.0.rc/lib/rails/railtie/configuration.rb:76:in `method_missing': undefined method `load_paths' for #<Rails::Application::Configuration:0x00000102aba970> (NoMethodError)
In order to compare the difference, I have created a new Rails application by executing "rails new [application_name]". But "load_paths" was written in there.
So I looked at railties-3.0.0.beta4 gem and railties-3.0.0.rc gem. By tracing the code, I found that in Rails::Engine::Configuration, attr_writer is changed from load_paths to autoload_paths.
I think that in order to avoid the confusion, autoload_paths should be written in application.rb when a new 3.0.0.rc application is created by "rails new".
ticket.latest-body:
I have just switched my existing Rails 3.0.0.beta4 application to 3.0.0.rc. And I got an error,
/Users/[user_name]/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-rc2/gems/railties-3.0.0.rc/lib/rails/railtie/configuration.rb:76:in `method_missing': undefined method `load_paths' for #<Rails::Application::Configuration:0x00000102aba970> (NoMethodError)
In order to compare the difference, I have created a new Rails application by executing "rails new [application_name]". But "load_paths" was written in there.
So I looked at railties-3.0.0.beta4 gem and railties-3.0.0.rc gem. By tracing the code, I found that in Rails::Engine::Configuration, attr_writer is changed from load_paths to autoload_paths.
I think that in order to avoid the confusion, autoload_paths should be written in application.rb when a new 3.0.0.rc application is created by "rails new".
ticket.original-body-html:
I have just switched my existing Rails 3.0.0.beta4 application to 3.0.0.rc.
And I got an error,

/Users/[user_name]/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-rc2/gems/railties-3.0.0.rc/lib/rails/railtie/configuration.rb:76:in method_missing': undefined methodload_paths' for #<Rails::Application::Configuration:0x00000102aba970> (NoMethodError)

In order to compare the difference, I have created a new Rails application by executing "rails new [application_name]". But "load_paths" was written in there.

So I looked at railties-3.0.0.beta4 gem and railties-3.0.0.rc gem. By tracing the code, I found that in Rails::Engine::Configuration, attr_writer is changed from load_paths to autoload_paths.

I think that in order to avoid the confusion, autoload_paths should be written in application.rb when a new 3.0.0.rc application is created by "rails new".

version.body:
I have just switched my existing Rails 3.0.0.beta4 application to 3.0.0.rc. And I got an error,
/Users/[user_name]/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-rc2/gems/railties-3.0.0.rc/lib/rails/railtie/configuration.rb:76:in `method_missing': undefined method `load_paths' for #<Rails::Application::Configuration:0x00000102aba970> (NoMethodError)
In order to compare the difference, I have created a new Rails application by executing "rails new [application_name]". But "load_paths" was written in there.
So I looked at railties-3.0.0.beta4 gem and railties-3.0.0.rc gem. By tracing the code, I found that in Rails::Engine::Configuration, attr_writer is changed from load_paths to autoload_paths.
I think that in order to avoid the confusion, autoload_paths should be written in application.rb when a new 3.0.0.rc application is created by "rails new".
version.body-html:
I have just switched my existing Rails 3.0.0.beta4 application to 3.0.0.rc.
And I got an error,

/Users/[user_name]/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-rc2/gems/railties-3.0.0.rc/lib/rails/railtie/configuration.rb:76:in method_missing': undefined methodload_paths' for #<Rails::Application::Configuration:0x00000102aba970> (NoMethodError)

In order to compare the difference, I have created a new Rails application by executing "rails new [application_name]". But "load_paths" was written in there.

So I looked at railties-3.0.0.beta4 gem and railties-3.0.0.rc gem. By tracing the code, I found that in Rails::Engine::Configuration, attr_writer is changed from load_paths to autoload_paths.

I think that in order to avoid the confusion, autoload_paths should be written in application.rb when a new 3.0.0.rc application is created by "rails new".
version.title: When a new Rails application is created by "rails new", autoload_paths instead of load_paths should be put in the generated application.rb

version.body:
P.S. I have just found that unless there is a Gemfile specifying rails 3.0.0.rc, rails command in any directory still uses the one for 3.0.0.beta4.
I apologize that I may have written the ticket too early and that I should investigate my environment more.
Here is what I get in the directory with the Gemfile: $ rails --version Rails 3.0.0.rc
And here is what I get in the directory without Gemfile: $ rails --version Rails 3.0.0.beta4
version.body-html:
P.S. I have just found that unless there is a Gemfile specifying rails 3.0.0.rc, rails command in any directory still uses the one for 3.0.0.beta4.

I apologize that I may have written the ticket too early and that I should investigate my environment more.

Here is what I get in the directory with the Gemfile:
$ rails --version Rails 3.0.0.rc

And here is what I get in the directory without Gemfile:
$ rails --version Rails 3.0.0.beta4
version.title: When a new Rails application is created by "rails new", autoload_paths instead of load_paths should be put in the generated application.rb
When a new Rails application is created by "rails new", autoload_paths instead of load_paths should be put in the generated application.rb

version.body: Is there any reason not to deprecate load_paths? These seemingly arbitrary name changes, with no deprecation warnings, make it harder for people to upgrade. If I write the deprecation warning will you accept it?
version.body-html: Is there any reason not to deprecate load_paths? These seemingly arbitrary name changes, with no deprecation warnings, make it harder for people to upgrade. If I write the deprecation warning will you accept it?
version.title: When a new Rails application is created by "rails new", autoload_paths instead of load_paths should be put in the generated application.rb

version.body: I had the same issue. It took me some time to fine that the method is now called ActiveSupport::Dependencies.autoload_paths instead of ActiveSupport::Dependencies.load_paths. Please use deprecations when making such changes.
version.body-html: I had the same issue. It took me some time to fine that the method is now called ActiveSupport::Dependencies.autoload_paths instead of ActiveSupport::Dependencies.load_paths. Please use deprecations when making such changes.
version.title: When a new Rails application is created by "rails new", autoload_paths instead of load_paths should be put in the generated application.rb

version.body: One of the things I have in common with the far more rich and famous Oprah Winfrey is a love of the nike shoes Free Run+ shoes. I began wearing them when they first debuted and my friend Carolyn praised them highly. nike sneaker are super flexible and meant to simulate barefoot walking. This supposedly helps strengthen your feet and ankles, nike air force 1 and as such I classify them as a toning dunks shoes.I've worn several versions of the nike dunk high Free Run shoes as my daily lifestyle shoe, air jordan 2011 good for shorter workouts of up to three miles. While I have friends who wear them on six mile walks (10K), I think they just don't have enough cushioning for going any further than that without beating up your feet.One other caution, air max shoes is notorious for a narrow toe box and these Nike air max 90 come in only one width.  My wide foot fit, but barely, Nike Air Griffey Max so I wore them without socks. They feel great without socks, but the basketball shoes quickly developed a terrible odor problem. Foot powder helped, and I can also recommend Stink Free lebron james shoes spray.

They feel great without socks, but the basketball shoes quickly developed a terrible odor problem. Foot powder helped, and I can also recommend Stink Free lebron james shoes spray.
